stattutor_problem.title: Body Image and Academic Performance of College Students
stattutor_problem.background: A student survey was conducted at a major university. Data were collected from a random sample of 239 undergraduate students, and the information that was collected included physical characteristics (such as height, handedness, etc.), study habits, academic performance and attitudes, and social behaviors. In this exercise, we will focus on exploring relationships between some of those variables. Note that the symbol * in the worksheet means that this observation is not available (this is known as a 'missing value').

variable.name: Seat
variable.description: Typical classroom seat location (F = Front, M = Middle, B = Back)

variable.name: WtFeel
variable.description: Does the student feel that he/she is: Underweight, About Right, Overweight

variable.name: Cheat
variable.description: Would the tell the instructor if he/she saw somebody cheating on exam? (No or Yes)

cdf_question.text: Out of the first ten students in the datafile, how many typically sit in the back of the classroom?

hints.hint: To answer each of the questions in this step, you'll need to look at the dataset you opened at the beginning of your StatTutor session, and examine the first few cases (rows).

In this dataset, each row represents a single student, so the first ten rows represent the first ten students. Look at the Seat column and count how many of the first ten students typically sit in the back of the classroom.
If you look at the first ten students (rows) in the dataset, you'll see that two of the students typically sit in the back of the classroom (coded by the letter B). These are students 5 and 8.

cdf_question.text: Out of the first ten students in the datafile, how many students have a college GPA which is higher than their high school GPA?

hints.hint: To answer each of the questions in this step, you'll need to look at the dataset you opened at the beginning of your StatTutor session, and examine the first few cases (rows).

In this dataset, each row represents a single student, so the first ten rows represent the first ten students. Look at the (college) GPA and HS GPA columns and count how many of the first ten students' college GPA is higher than their high school GPA
If you look at the first ten students (rows) in the dataset, you'll see that in three cases (students 4, 5,and 9), the college GPA is higher than their high school GPA.

cdf_question.text: What is the typical seat of the student with the highest GPA among the first ten students in the datafile? (use the code as your answer)

hints.hint: To answer each of the questions in this step, you'll need to look at the dataset you opened at the beginning of your StatTutor session, and examine the first few cases (rows).

In this dataset, each row represents a single student, so the first ten rows represent the first ten students. Among the first ten students (rows), look for the student with the highest GPA, and report where he or she typically sits (use the letter code F, M, or B as your answer).
Among the first ten students, the one with the highest GPA is student 9 (GPA 3.77). This student typically sits in the middle (M) of the classroom.

main_question.text: Is there a relationship between students' college GPAs and their high school GPAs?

consider_question.question: Before analyzing the data and discovering the relationship between students' high school GPAs and their college GPAs, try to predict what the data will show (use your own experience and intuition).

our_answer.text: Typically, students who perform well in high school (as measured by a high GPA) will also tend to perform well in college (also measured by a high GPA). Therefore, one could expect that the data will show a similar trend.
Here is the Minitab output:
The scatterplot displays a positive linear relationship between HS GPA and college GPA. The correlation coefficient r is 0.716, indicating that the positive linear relationship is moderately strong.
Here is the StatCrunch output:
The scatterplot displays a positive linear relationship between HS GPA and college GPA. The correlation coefficient r is 0.716, indicating that the positive linear relationship is moderately strong.
Here is the Excel output:
The scatterplot displays a positive linear relationship between HS_GPA and college GPA. The correlation coefficient r is 0.716, indicating that the positive linear relationship is moderately strong.
The scatterplot displays a positive linear relationship between HS GPA and college GPA. The correlation coefficient r is 0.716, indicating that the positive linear relationship is moderately strong.
Here is the TI output:
The scatterplot displays a positive linear relationship between HS GPA and college GPA. The correlation coefficient r is 0.716, indicating that the positive linear relationship is moderately strong.

consider_results.question: What do the results you got indicate about the relationship between students' high school GPAs and their college GPAs?

our_answer.text: The results indicate that in general the students who have a higher high school GPA will tend to also have a higher college GPA, and vice versa. The results further indicate that this relationship is linear and that it is moderately strong.

thought_question.question:
Since the relationship between the students' high school GPAs and college GPAs is linear (as displayed by the scatterplot and supported by the correlation coefficient r being relatively close to 1), it makes sense to go ahead and find the regression line - the line that best fits the linear pattern of our data.

To do this in Minitab:
  • Choose: Stat --> Regression --> Fitted Line Plot...
  • Next to 'Response(Y)' put the response variable (or double click on it in the left panel).
  • Next to 'Predictor(X)' put the explanatory variable (or double click on it).
  • Click OK

(You should see the scatterplot with the regression line plotted on it. You'll find the regression equation at the top of the graph window as well as in the session window).

Based on the result you got, answer the following questions in the textbox below:
(a) What is the regression equation?
(b) Does the line fit the pattern of the data well?
(c) Use the regression equation to predict the college GPA of a high school senior whose GPA is 3.45.

Since the relationship between the students' high school GPAs and college GPAs is linear (as displayed by the scatterplot and supported by the correlation coefficient r being relatively close to 1), it makes sense to go ahead and find the regression line - the line that best fits the linear pattern of our data.

To do this in StatCrunch:
  • Choose: Stat --> Regression --> Simple Linear
  • For the X variable select the explanatory variable and for the Y variable select the response variable
  • Press Next three times until you come to the window with Graphics options
  • Click 'Plot the fitted line'
  • Press Calculate

(Note that the calculations appear on the first page. Press Next to see the regression line on the second page.).

Based on the result you got, answer the following questions in the textbox below:
(a) What is the regression equation?
(b) Does the line fit the pattern of the data well?
(c) Use the regression equation to predict the college GPA of a high school senior whose GPA is 3.45.

Since the relationship between the students' high school GPAs and college GPAs is linear (as displayed by the scatterplot and supported by the correlation coefficient r being relatively close to 1), it makes sense to go ahead and find the regression line - the line that best fits the linear pattern of our data.

To do this in Excel:
  • Right-click on one of the data points in your scatterplot and choose 'Add Trendline' from the pop-up menu
  • In the next window that appears, under the 'Type' tab, select 'Linear'. Under the 'Options' tab, make sure that 'Display equation on chart' and 'Display R-squared value on chart' are both checked.
  • Click OK

You should now see the scatterplot with the regression line plotted on it, as well as the regression equation and the R-squared value.

Based on the result you got, answer the following questions in the textbox below:
(a) What is the regression equation?
(b) Does the line fit the pattern of the data well?
(c) Use the regression equation to predict the college GPA of a high school senior whose GPA is 3.45.

Since the relationship between the students' high school GPAs and college GPAs is linear (as displayed by the scatterplot and supported by the correlation coefficient r being relatively close to 1), it makes sense to go ahead and find the regression line - the line that best fits the linear pattern of our data.

To do this in R, use the following commands:
  • L=lm(data$GPA~data$HS_GPA);
  • abline(L);
  • cf=coefficients(L);
  • lt=paste("GPA = ",round(cf[1],2),"+",round(cf[2],2),"HS_GPA")
  • legend(1.7,4.3,lt)

(You should see the scatterplot with the regression line plotted on it. You'll find the regression equation at the top of the graph window).

Based on the result you got, answer the following questions in the textbox below:
(a) What is the regression equation?
(b) Does the line fit the pattern of the data well?
(c) Use the regression equation to predict the college GPA of a high school senior whose GPA is 3.45.

Since the relationship between the students' high school GPAs and college GPAs is linear (as displayed by the scatterplot and supported by the correlation coefficient r being relatively close to 1), it makes sense to go ahead and find the regression line - the line that best fits the linear pattern of our data.

To do this in the TI calculator:

TI Instructions to draw the regression line (Line of Best Fit)
  • The TI calculator stores the last regression line that you calculated until you calculate another one.
  • Choose y=
  • Now cut and paste the values for a and b.
  • To get the y-intercept (a), choose VARS/5:Statistics.
  • Choose EQ (right arrow twice).
  • Choose 2:a
  • Press the + button.
  • To get the slope (b), choose VARS/5:Statistics.
  • Choose EQ (right arrow twice).
  • Choose 3:b
  • Press the X,T, ,n button.
  • Note: As long as you donâ€™t change Y1, each time you find another regression line, the a and b will automatically save the new values and the new line will be graphed.
  • You can toggle Y1 on and off. When the = is highlighted, the graph is ON. To turn it OFF, use the left arrow to highlight the =, then press ENTER. Repeat to turn graph back on.
  • If youâ€™ve set up the scatterplot and set up Y1=, you can ZOOM/9:ZoomStat to see the regression line plotted on the scatterplot.

TI Instructions to use the regression line for predictions
  • Method 1: (low tech) Write down the a (y-intercept) and b (slope) values for the regression line (y=a+bx).
  • To find the predicted y-value for any x, simply add the value of a plus the value of b times x.
  • Note: Remember order of operations. Multiplication comes before addition. If you use your TI, the TI follows the standard order of operations. However, it is wrong to do:
  • a + b ENTER
  • * x ENTER
  • This will force the addition to be performed before the multiplication, which is incorrect.
  • Method 2: If youâ€™ve set Y1 = a + bx.
  • Go to a home screen (press 2ND/QUIT).
  • Choose Y1 (VARS/Y-VARS/1:Function/1:Y1).
  • Press left parenthesis, the x-value, right parenthesis.
  • For example, to find the predicted y-value when x is 3.45.
  • Y1(3.45)
  • Press ENTER


Based on the result you got, answer the following questions in the textbox below:
(a) What is the regression equation?
(b) Does the line fit the pattern of the data well?
(c) Use the regression equation to predict the college GPA of a high school senior whose GPA is 3.45.

our_answer.text: (a) The regression equation is given in the following output:

(b) The graph displays a pretty good fit of the regression line to the data.

(c) The predicted GPA for a student whose HS GPA is 3.45 is: 1.073 + 0.6192 * 3.45 = 3.21.

(b) The graph displays a pretty good fit of the regression line to the data.

(c) The predicted GPA for a student whose HS GPA is 3.45 is: 1.073 + 0.6192 * 3.45 = 3.21.
(a) The regression equation is given in the following output:

(b) The graph displays a pretty good fit of the regression line to the data.

(c) The predicted GPA for a student whose HS GPA is 3.45 is: 0.6192 * 3.45 + 1.0727 = 3.21.
(a) The regression equation is given in the following output:

(b) The graph displays a pretty good fit of the regression line to the data.

(c) The predicted GPA for a student whose HS GPA is 3.45 is: 1.07 + 0.62 * 3.45 = 3.21.
(a) The regression equation is given in the following output:
(b) The graph displays a pretty good fit of the regression line to the data.
(c) The predicted GPA for a student whose HS GPA is 3.45 is: 1.073 + 0.6192 * 3.45 = 3.21.

thought_question.hint: Use the regression equation to do the prediction by calculating the GPA when the HS GPA is set to 3.45.

our_answer.text:
• The results are consistent with what can be expected.

  • We should intervene and counsel students while still in high school. Knowing that students with low GPAs are at risk of not doing well in college, colleges should develop programs, such as peer or faculty mentors, for these students.

main_question.text: Are there differences between males and females with respect to body image?

consider_question.question: Before analyzing the data and discovering whether there is a gender effect on body image, try to predict what the data will show (use your own experience and intuition).

our_answer.text: There is no right or wrong answer here. In the past, body image was a problem associated mostly with females. These days, however, this is no longer the case.
The counts and conditional percents are summarized in the following table provided by Minitab (which also highlights the comparison between males and females).

Note that as stated in red, for each cell, the conditional percents appear below the cell count.

The percentages for About Right, Overweight, and Underweight for females are 73.79%, 22.07%, and 4.14%, respectively. The same percentages for males are: 66.67%, 17.86%, 15.48%.
The counts and conditional percents are summarized in the following tables.
The percentages for About Right, Overweight, and Underweight for females are 73.79%, 22.07%, and 4.138%, respectively. The same percentages for males are: 66.67%, 17.86%, 15.48%.
The counts and conditional percents are summarized in the following tables.

The percentages for About Right, Overweight, Underweight, and Missing for females are 71.33%, 21.33%, 4.00%, and 3.33% respectively. The same percentages for males are: 65.12%, 17.44%, 15.12%, and 2.33%.
The counts and conditional percents are summarized in the following tables provided by R, which show the comparison between males and females.
The percentages for About Right, Overweight, and Underweight for females are 73.79%, 22.07%, and 4.14%, respectively. The same percentages for males are: 66.67%, 17.86%, 15.48%.
The counts and conditional percents are summarized in the following tables.

The percentages for About Right, Overweight, Underweight, and Missing for females are 71.33%, 21.33%, 4.00%, mad 3.33% respectively. The same percentages for males are: 65.12%, 17.44%, 15.12%, and 2.33%.

consider_results.question: What do the results you got indicate about how males and females differ with respect to their body image?

our_answer.text:
The results indicate that males and females do differ with respect to their body image. A larger proportion of females felt that their weight was about right (roughly 74% vs. 67% for males). Among the students who did not feel that their weight was about right, there was a difference between males and females. Roughly the same proportion of male students were concerned about being overweight as being underweight (18% vs. 15.5%), while females were mostly concerned about being overweight (22% vs. only 4% for underweight).

It is interesting to find that actually a larger proportion of males are concerned with their body image compared to females. Also, it makes sense that being underweight is more of a concern for males than it is for females because of the current quest of many males for a big, muscular body and the quest for females to emulate thin fashion models.

The results indicate that males and females do differ with respect to their body image. A larger proportion of females felt that their weight was about right (roughly 74% vs. 67% for males). Among the students who did not feel that their weight was about right, there was a difference between males and females. Roughly the same proportion of male students were concerned about being overweight as being underweight (18% vs. 15.5%), while females were mostly concerned about being overweight (22% vs. only 4% for underweight).

It is interesting to find that actually a larger proportion of males are concerned with their body image compared to females. Also, it makes sense that being underweight is more of a concern for males than it is for females because of the current quest of many males for a big, muscular body and the quest for females to emulate thin fashion models.

The results indicate that males and females do differ with respect to their body image. A larger proportion of females felt that their weight was about right (roughly 71% vs. 65% for males). Among the students who did not feel that their weight was about right, there was a difference between males and females. Roughly the same proportion of male students were concerned about being overweight as being underweight (17% vs. 15%), while females were mostly concerned about being overweight (21% vs. only 4% for underweight). There were roughly the same percentage of females and males that did not respond (3% vs. 2%).

It is interesting to find that actually a larger proportion of males are concerned with their body image compared to females. Also, it makes sense that being underweight is more of a concern for males than it is for females because of the current quest of many males for a big, muscular body and the quest for females to emulate thin fashion models.

The results indicate that males and females do differ with respect to their body image. A larger proportion of females felt that their weight was about right (roughly 74% vs. 67% for males). Among the students who did not feel that their weight was about right, there was a difference between males and females. Roughly the same proportion of male students were concerned about being overweight as being underweight (18% vs. 15.5%), while females were mostly concerned about being overweight (22% vs. only 4% for underweight).

It is interesting to find that actually a larger proportion of males are concerned with their body image compared to females. Also, it makes sense that being underweight is more of a concern for males than it is for females because of the current quest of many males for a big, muscular body and the quest for females to emulate thin fashion models.

The results indicate that males and females do differ with respect to their body image. A larger proportion of females felt that their weight was about right (roughly 71% vs. 65% for males). Among the students who did not feel that their weight was about right, there was a difference between males and females. Roughly the same proportion of male students were concerned about being overweight as being underweight (17% vs. 15%), while females were mostly concerned about being overweight (21% vs. only 4% for underweight). There were roughly the same percentage of females and males that did not respond (3% vs. 2%).

It is interesting to find that actually a larger proportion of males are concerned with their body image compared to females. Also, it makes sense that being underweight is more of a concern for males than it is for females because of the current quest of many males for a big, muscular body and the quest for females to emulate thin fashion models.

• As we expected, both males and females have issues with body image.

  • It would be useful to report these results to people who counsel students, since concerns about body image can result in poor college performance and health issues.

main_question.text: Is students' academic performance in college related to their typical seating location in class?

consider_question.question: Before analyzing the data and discovering the relationship between student's academic performance and their typical seat in class, try to predict what the data will show (use your own experience and intuition).

our_answer.text: One would expect that generally, students who sit in the front or middle of the classroom are the more conscientious students and therefore are also students with higher GPAs. This is of course, a gross generalization. It will be interesting to see whether the data will support this.
Here is the Minitab output:

When comparing distributions across groups, we need to address the issues of center, spread and outliers:

Center: The median GPA of the "F group" (3.3) is higher than that of the two other groups (both of which are 3.0).

Spread: Differences in spread between the three groups are not huge, but still exist. The "M group" has the largest spread (range = 2.47, IQR = .74) followed by the "F group" (range = 2.18, IQR = .7), and then the "B group" (range = 2.06, IQR = .64).

Outliers: According to the output, one observation in the "F group" was classified as an outlier. However, it is a very mild outlier.
Here is the StatCrunch output:

When comparing distributions across groups, we need to address the issues of center, spread and outliers:

Center: The median GPA of the "F group" (3.33) is higher than that of the two other groups (both of which are 3.0).

Spread: Differences in spread between the three groups are not huge, but still exist. The "M group" has the largest spread (range = 2.47, IQR = .74) followed by the "F group" (range = 2.18, IQR = .7), and then the "B group" (range = 2.06, IQR = .58).

Outliers: There are no outliers.
Here is the Excel output:

Center: The median GPA of the "F group" (3.33) is higher than that of the two other groups (both of which are 3.0).

Spread: Differences in spread between the three groups are not huge, but still exist. The "M group" has the largest spread (range = 2.47, IQR = 0.725) followed by the "F group" (range = 2.18, IQR = 0.7), and then the "B group" (range = 2.06, IQR = 0.56).

Outliers: There are no outliers.

When comparing distributions across groups, we need to address the issues of center, spread and outliers:

Center: The median GPA of the "F group" (3.3) is higher than that of the two other groups (both of which are 3.0).

Spread: Differences in spread between the three groups are not huge, but still exist. The "M group" has the largest spread (range = 2.47, IQR = 0.725) followed by the "F group" (range = 2.18, IQR = 0.7), and then the "B group" (range = 2.06, IQR = 0.559).

Outliers: According to the output, one observation in the "F group" was classified as an outlier. However, it is a very mild outlier.
Here is the TI output:

When comparing distributions across groups, we need to address the issues of center, spread and outliers:

Center: The median GPA of the "F group" (3.3) is higher than that of the two other groups (both of which are 3.0).

Spread: Differences in spread between the three groups are not huge, but still exist. The "M group" has the largest spread (range = 2.47, IQR = .74) followed by the "F group" (range = 2.18, IQR = .7), and then the "B group" (range = 2.06, IQR = .58).

Outliers: According to the output, one observation in the "F group" was classified as an outlier. However, it is a very mild outlier.

consider_results.question: What do the results you got indicate about the relationship between typical seating location in class and academic performance in college?

our_answer.text: The data suggest that GPA is somewhat related to seating location. In general, the GPAs of students who sit in the front of the classroom are slightly higher than those of students who sit in the middle or in the back. However, there is a lot of variation in GPA within each of the three groups, and therefore the student's typical seating location should not really be used as an indication of his/her performance in college.

• The conclusions support what we would naturally expect. It was interesting to find hardly any differences in GPAs between students who sit in the middle of the classroom and those who sit in the back.

  • If instructors were made aware of these results, they could encourage students who are doing poorly to change their seat location. Also, students should be made aware that where they sit might impact their performance.

In the first and third question, we examined two explanatory variables for the response variable college GPA. We found that generally, students who have a high high school GPA will tend to also have a high college GPA, and that students who typically sit in the front of the classroom generally have a higher GPA than those who sit in the middle or the back. In the second question, we investigated a completely unrelated issue, the differences in body image between males and females. We were surprised to find that actually a higher percentage of females were satisfied with their weight than males.
